content.html:
I‚Äôve been spending a while running on reduced brain capacity lately so, to ease myself back into thinking like a programmer, I upgraded my preferred feed reader FreshRSS to version 1.20.0 ‚Äì which was released a couple of weeks ago ‚Äì and tried out what I believe is its killer new feature: HTML + XPath scraping.

I‚Äôve been using RSS1 for about 20 years and I love it. It feels great to be able to curate my updates based on ‚Äúwhat I care about‚Äù, and not on ‚Äúwhat some social network thinks I should care about‚Äù, to keep things to read later, to prioritise effectively based on my own categorisation, to consume content offline and have my to-read list synchronise later, etc.

RSS never went away, of course (what do you think a podcast is?), but it got steamrollered out of the public eye by big companies who make their money out of keeping your eyes on their platforms and off the open Web. But it feels like it‚Äôs slowly coming back: even Substack ‚Äì whose entire thing is that an email client is more-convenient than a feed reader for most people ‚Äì launched an RSS reader this week!

I love RSS so much that I routinely retrofit other people‚Äôs websites with feeds just so I can subscribe to them: I even published the tool I use to do so! Whether filtering sports headlines out of BBC News, turning retro webcomics into ‚Äúreading lists‚Äù so I can track my progress, or just working around sites that really should have feeds but refuse to, I just love sidestepping these ‚Äúmissing feeds‚Äù. My friend Beverley has a blog without any kind of feed, so I added one so I could subscribe to it. Magic.

But with FreshRSS 1.20.0, I no longer have to maintain my own tool to get this brilliant functionality, and I‚Äôm overjoyed. Let‚Äôs look at how it works by re-subscribing to Beverley‚Äôs blog but without a middleware tool.

In the latest version of FreshRSS, when you add a new feed to your reader, a new section ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù is available. Unfold it, and you can change from the default (‚ÄúRSS / Atom‚Äù) to the new option ‚ÄúHTML + XPath (Web scraping)‚Äù. Put a human-readable page address rather than a feed address into the ‚ÄúFeed URL‚Äù field and fill these fields to tell FreshRSS how to parse the page to get the content you want. Note that it doesn‚Äôt matter if the web page isn‚Äôt valid XML (e.g. missing closing tags) because it‚Äôs going to get run through PHP‚Äôs DOMDocument anyway which will ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù for some really sloppy code if needed.

You‚Äôll need to use XPath to express how to find a ‚Äúfeed item‚Äù on the page. Here‚Äôs the rules I used for https://webdevbev.co.uk/blog.html (many of these fields were optional ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt have to do this much work):

  • Feed title: //h1
    I override this anyway in FreshRSS, so I could just have used the a string, but I wanted the XPath practice. There‚Äôs only one <h1> on the page, and it can be considered the ‚Äútitle‚Äù of the feed.
  • Finding items: //li[@class="blog__post-preview"]
    Each ‚Äúpost‚Äù on the page is an <li class="blog__post-preview">.
  • Item titles: descendant::h2
    Each post has a <h2> which is the post title. The descendant:: selector scopes the search to each post as found above.
  • Item content: descendant::p[3]
    Beverley‚Äôs static site generator template puts the post summary in the third paragraph of the <li>, which we can select like this.
  • Item link: descendant::h2/a/@href
    This expects a URL, so we need the /@href to make sure we get the value of the <h2><a href="...">, rather than its contents.
  • Item thumbnail: descendant::img[@class="blog__image--preview"]/@src
    Again, this expects a URL, which we get from the <img src="...">.
  • Item author: "Beverley Newing"
    Beverley‚Äôs blog doesn‚Äôt host any guest posts, so I just use a string literal here.
  • Item date: substring-after(descendant::p[@class="blog__date-posted"], "Date posted: ")
    This is the only complicated one: the published dates on Beverley‚Äôs blog aren‚Äôt explicitly marked-up, but part of a string that begins with the words ‚ÄúDate posted: ‚Äú, so I use XPath‚Äôs substring-after function to strtip this. The result gets passed to PHP‚Äôs strtotime(), which is pretty tolerant of different date formats (although not of the words ‚ÄúDate posted:‚Äù it turns out!).

I hope that this is just the beginning for this new killer feature in FreshRSS: there‚Äôs so much more it can be and do. But for now, I‚Äôm still mighty impressed that I can begin to phase-out my use of my relatively resource-intensive feed-building middleware and use my feed reader to do more and more of the heavy lifting for which I love it so much.

I also love that this functionally adds h-feed support in by the back door. I‚Äôd still prefer there to be a ‚Äúh-feed‚Äù option in the ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù drop-down, but at least I can add such support manually, now!

Footnotes

1 When I say RSS, I mean feed. Most of the feeds I subscribe to are RSS feeds, but some are Atom feeds, h-feed, etc. But I can‚Äôt get over the old-fashioned name, and I don‚Äôt care to try.

I‚Äôve been spending a while running on reduced brain capacity lately so, to ease myself back into thinking like a programmer, I upgraded my preferred feed reader FreshRSS to version 1.20.0 ‚Äì which was released a couple of weeks ago ‚Äì and tried out what I believe is its killer new feature: HTML + XPath scraping. Screenshot showing Beverley Newing's weblog; two articles are visible - Paperback copy of 'Disability Visibility', edited by Alice Wong, next to a cup of tea Setting up an Accessibility Book Club, published on 1 March 2022, and Reflecting on 2021, published on 1 January 2022. Screenshot showing Beverley Newing's weblog; two articles are visible - Paperback copy of 'Disability Visibility', edited by Alice Wong, next to a cup of tea Setting up an Accessibility Book Club, published on 1 March 2022, and Reflecting on 2021, published on 1 January 2022. I like to keep up-to-date with my friend Bev‚Äôs blog, but they don‚Äôt have an RSS feed. I‚Äôve been using RSS1 for about 20 years and I love it. It feels great to be able to curate my updates based on ‚Äúwhat I care about‚Äù, and not on ‚Äúwhat some social network thinks I should care about‚Äù, to keep things to read later, to prioritise effectively based on my own categorisation, to consume content offline and have my to-read list synchronise later, etc. RSS never went away, of course (what do you think a podcast is?), but it got steamrollered out of the public eye by big companies who make their money out of keeping your eyes on their platforms and off the open Web. But it feels like it‚Äôs slowly coming back: even Substack ‚Äì whose entire thing is that an email client is more-convenient than a feed reader for most people ‚Äì launched an RSS reader this week! A smartphone on a wooden surface. The screen shows the FeedMe app, showing the most-recent blog post from Beverley's blog. A smartphone on a wooden surface. The screen shows the FeedMe app, showing the most-recent blog post from Beverley's blog. My day usually starts in my feed reader, accessed via the FeedMe app from my mobile (although FreshRSS provides a reasonably good responsive interface out-of-the-box!) I love RSS so much that I routinely retrofit other people‚Äôs websites with feeds just so I can subscribe to them: I even published the tool I use to do so! Whether filtering sports headlines out of BBC News, turning retro webcomics into ‚Äúreading lists‚Äù so I can track my progress, or just working around sites that really should have feeds but refuse to, I just love sidestepping these ‚Äúmissing feeds‚Äù. My friend Beverley has a blog without any kind of feed, so I added one so I could subscribe to it. Magic. But with FreshRSS 1.20.0, I no longer have to maintain my own tool to get this brilliant functionality, and I‚Äôm overjoyed. Let‚Äôs look at how it works by re-subscribing to Beverley‚Äôs blog but without a middleware tool. Screenshot showing FetchRSS being used to graphically create a feed from Beverley's blog. Screenshot showing FetchRSS being used to graphically create a feed from Beverley's blog. This post is about to get pretty technical. If you don‚Äôt want to learn some XPath but just want to make a feed out of a web page, use a graphical tool like FetchRSS. In the latest version of FreshRSS, when you add a new feed to your reader, a new section ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù is available. Unfold it, and you can change from the default (‚ÄúRSS / Atom‚Äù) to the new option ‚ÄúHTML + XPath (Web scraping)‚Äù. Put a human-readable page address rather than a feed address into the ‚ÄúFeed URL‚Äù field and fill these fields to tell FreshRSS how to parse the page to get the content you want. Note that it doesn‚Äôt matter if the web page isn‚Äôt valid XML (e.g. missing closing tags) because it‚Äôs going to get run through PHP‚Äôs DOMDocument anyway which will ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù for some really sloppy code if needed. Browser debugger running document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() on Beverley's weblog and getting the first blog entry. Browser debugger running document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() on Beverley's weblog and getting the first blog entry. You can use your browser‚Äôs debugger to help check your XPath rules: here I‚Äôve run¬† document.evaluate('//li[@class="blog__post-preview"]', document).iterateNext() and got back the first blog post on the page, so I know I‚Äôm on the right track.You‚Äôll need to use XPath to express how to find a ‚Äúfeed item‚Äù on the page. Here‚Äôs the rules I used for https://webdevbev.co.uk/blog.html (many of these fields were optional ‚Äì I didn‚Äôt have to do this much work): Feed title: //h1 I override this anyway in FreshRSS, so I could just have used the a string, but I wanted the XPath practice. There‚Äôs only one

on the page, and it can be considered the ‚Äútitle‚Äù of the feed. Finding items: //li[@class="blog__post-preview"] Each ‚Äúpost‚Äù on the page is an
  • . Item titles: descendant::h2 Each post has a

    which is the post title. The descendant:: selector scopes the search to each post as found above. Item content: descendant::p[3] Beverley‚Äôs static site generator template puts the post summary in the third paragraph of the
  • , which we can select like this. Item link: descendant::h2/a/@href This expects a URL, so we need the /@href to make sure we get the value of the

    , rather than its contents. Item thumbnail: descendant::img[@class="blog__image--preview"]/@src Again, this expects a URL, which we get from the . Item author: "Beverley Newing" Beverley‚Äôs blog doesn‚Äôt host any guest posts, so I just use a string literal here. Item date: substring-after(descendant::p[@class="blog__date-posted"], "Date posted: ") This is the only complicated one: the published dates on Beverley‚Äôs blog aren‚Äôt explicitly marked-up, but part of a string that begins with the words ‚ÄúDate posted: ‚Äú, so I use XPath‚Äôs substring-after function to strtip this. The result gets passed to PHP‚Äôs strtotime(), which is pretty tolerant of different date formats (although not of the words ‚ÄúDate posted:‚Äù it turns out!). Screenshot: Adding a "HTML + XPath (Web scraping)" feed via FreshRSS. Screenshot: Adding a "HTML + XPath (Web scraping)" feed via FreshRSS. I‚Äôd love one day for FreshRSS to provide some kind of ‚Äúpreview‚Äù feature here so you can see what you‚Äôll expect to get back, as you work. That, and support for different input types (JSON, perhaps?), perhaps other selectors (I find CSS-style selectors much simpler than XPath), and maybe even an option to execute Javascript on the page before scraping (I use this in my own toolchain, but that‚Äôs just because I want to have my cake and eat it too). But this is still all pretty awesome. I hope that this is just the beginning for this new killer feature in FreshRSS: there‚Äôs so much more it can be and do. But for now, I‚Äôm still mighty impressed that I can begin to phase-out my use of my relatively resource-intensive feed-building middleware and use my feed reader to do more and more of the heavy lifting for which I love it so much. I also love that this functionally adds h-feed support in by the back door. I‚Äôd still prefer there to be a ‚Äúh-feed‚Äù option in the ‚ÄúType of feed source‚Äù drop-down, but at least I can add such support manually, now! Beverley's blog post "Setting up an Accessibility Book Club" in FreshRSS. Beverley's blog post "Setting up an Accessibility Book Club" in FreshRSS. The finished result: Bev‚Äôs blog posts appear directly in my feed reader, even though they don‚Äôt have a feed, and now without going through the middleware I‚Äôd set up for that purpose. Footnotes1 When I say RSS, I mean feed. Most of the feeds I subscribe to are RSS feeds, but some are Atom feeds, h-feed, etc. But I can‚Äôt get over the old-fashioned name, and I don‚Äôt care to try.

name: All the game descriptions from the sale

content.html:
You‚Äôve got 37 unpaid parking tickets. You just got pulled over for speeding. In your defense, you were texting your sister about how drunk you are. Plus there‚Äôs all that blood on your windshield. Obviously you know it‚Äôs deer blood, but the police officers walking toward your vehicle don‚Äôt. Still, in the time it takes them to figure that out, maybe you‚Äôll sober up. Or escape on foot! Either way, it‚Äôll probably be fine.

User Tags: Poor Choices / Story Rich / Multiple Endings / Parkour

Collect dead seagulls and build a zoo to house them all. Beautify the zoo with artistic flair and deodorizing sprays. Design creative group promotions to stir up interest! Is that a customer? You‚Äôd better hope it‚Äôs not the owner of the live seagull zoo down the street, because he‚Äôs probably got some questions.

User Tags: Hard Work / Supply / Demand / Diseases & Parasites

‚Ä¶

Claire Hummel

Claire Hummel produced fake video game art for the Steam Summer Sale, which was already excellent, but when @g-a-y-g-o-y-l-e reblogged, asking for more context, Claire delivered and then some. Every single one of these ‚Äúgame descriptions‚Äù is a special kind of comedy gold‚Ä¶ and yet somehow believable from the store that sells us Dream Daddy, IKEA VR Pancake Kitchen, Organ Trail, Oh‚Ä¶ Sir!! The Insult Simulator, and Goat Simulator (all of which I own copies of). Go read the full list.

content.html:
I managed to dodge infection for 922 days of the Covid pandemic1, but it caught up with me eventually.

Frankly, it‚Äôs surprising that it took this long. We‚Äôve always been careful, in accordance with guidance at any given time, nd we all got our jabs and boosters as soon as we were able‚Ä¶ but conversely: we‚Äôve got school-age children who naturally seem to be the biggest disease vectors imaginable. Our youngest, in fact, already had Covid, but the rest of us managed to dodge it perhaps thanks to all these precautions.

Luckily I‚Äôm not suffering too badly, probably thanks to the immunisation. It‚Äôs still not great, but I dread to think how it might have been without the benefit of the jab! A minor fever came and went, and then it‚Äôs just been a few days of coughing, exhaustion, and‚Ä¶ the most-incredible level of brain-fog.

I‚Äôve taken the week off work to recover, which was a wise choice. As well as getting rest, it‚Äôs meant that I‚Äôve managed to avoid writing production code with my addled brain! Instead, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time chilling in bed and watching all of the films that I‚Äôd been meaning to! This week, I‚Äôve watched:

  • Peggy Sue Got Married (y‚Äôknow, that other mid-1980s movie about time travel and being a teenager in the 1950s). It was okay; some bits of the direction were spectacular for its age, like the ‚Äúthrough the mirror‚Äù filming.
  • Fall. I enjoyed this more than I expected to. It‚Äôs not great, but while I spent most of the time complaining about the lack of believability in the setting and the characters‚Äô reactions, the acting was good and the tension ‚Äúworked‚Äù: it was ocassionally pretty vertigo-inducing, and that‚Äôs not just because I‚Äôve been having some Covid-related dizziness!
  • RRR. Oh my god this Tollywood action spectacle was an adventure. At one point it‚Äôs a bromantic buddy comedy, then later there‚Äôs a dance-off, then for a while there‚Äôs a wonderful ‚Äúeven language can‚Äôt divide us‚Äù romance, but then later a man picks up a motorcycle with one hand and uses it to beat up an entire army, and somehow it all feels like it belongs together. The symbolism‚Äôs so thick you can spread it (tl;dr: colonialism bad), but it‚Äôs still a riot of a film.
  • Cyrano, which I feel was under-rated but that could just be that I have a soft spot for the story‚Ä¶ and a love of musical theatre.
  • Also, at times when I didn‚Äôt think my brain had the focus for something new, I re-watched Dude, Where‚Äôs My Car? because I figured a stoner comedy that re-replains the plot every 20 minutes or so was about as good as I could expect my brain to handle at the time, and Everything Everywhere All At Once which I‚Äôve now seen three times and loved every single one: it‚Äôs one of my favourite films.

Anyway: hopefully next week I‚Äôll be feeling more normal and my poor Covid-struck brain can be trusted with code again. Until then: time to try to rest some more.

Footnotes

1 Based on the World Health Organisation‚Äôs declaration of the outbreak being a pandemic on 11 March 2020 and my positive test on 19 September 2022, I stayed uninfected for two years, six months, one week, and one day. But who‚Äôs counting?
content.value:
I managed to dodge infection for 922 days of the Covid pandemic1, but it caught up with me eventually.
 Lateral flow test, with "DAN" written on it, showing a solid control line and a very clear solid test line: a clear positive result.  Lateral flow test, with "DAN" written on it, showing a solid control line and a very clear solid test line: a clear positive result. Well, shit.
Frankly, it‚Äôs surprising that it took this long. We‚Äôve always been careful, in accordance with guidance at any given time, nd we all got our jabs and boosters as soon as we were able‚Ä¶ but conversely: we‚Äôve got school-age children who naturally seem to be the biggest disease vectors imaginable. Our youngest, in fact, already had Covid, but the rest of us managed to dodge it perhaps thanks to all these precautions.
 Vials of Covid vaccine scattered across a red background. Photo courtesy Maksim Goncharenok.  Vials of Covid vaccine scattered across a red background. Photo courtesy Maksim Goncharenok. The vaccine provide protection, but it‚Äôs not a magical force-field.
Luckily I‚Äôm not suffering too badly, probably thanks to the immunisation. It‚Äôs still not great, but I dread to think how it might have been without the benefit of the jab! A minor fever came and went, and then it‚Äôs just been a few days of coughing, exhaustion, and‚Ä¶ the most-incredible level of brain-fog.
 Dan with the dog, in the garden.  Dan with the dog, in the garden. Today, for example, I completey blanked the word ‚Äútoilet‚Äù and struggled for some time to express to the dog why I‚Äôd brought her into the garden, while she stared at me expectantly.
I‚Äôve taken the week off work to recover, which was a wise choice. As well as getting rest, it‚Äôs meant that I‚Äôve managed to avoid writing production code with my addled brain! Instead, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time chilling in bed and watching all of the films that I‚Äôd been meaning to! This week, I‚Äôve watched:

Peggy Sue Got Married (y‚Äôknow, that other mid-1980s movie about time travel and being a teenager in the 1950s). It was okay; some bits of the direction were spectacular for its age, like the ‚Äúthrough the mirror‚Äù filming.
Fall. I enjoyed this more than I expected to. It‚Äôs not great, but while I spent most of the time complaining about the lack of believability in the setting and the characters‚Äô reactions, the acting was good and the tension ‚Äúworked‚Äù: it was ocassionally pretty vertigo-inducing, and that‚Äôs not just because I‚Äôve been having some Covid-related dizziness!
RRR. Oh my god this Tollywood action spectacle was an adventure. At one point it‚Äôs a bromantic buddy comedy, then later there‚Äôs a dance-off, then for a while there‚Äôs a wonderful ‚Äúeven language can‚Äôt divide us‚Äù romance, but then later a man picks up a motorcycle with one hand and uses it to beat up an entire army, and somehow it all feels like it belongs together. The symbolism‚Äôs so thick you can spread it (tl;dr: colonialism bad), but it‚Äôs still a riot of a film.
Cyrano, which I feel was under-rated but that could just be that I have a soft spot for the story‚Ä¶ and a love of musical theatre.
Also, at times when I didn‚Äôt think my brain had the focus for something new, I re-watched Dude, Where‚Äôs My Car? because I figured a stoner comedy that re-replains the plot every 20 minutes or so was about as good as I could expect my brain to handle at the time, and Everything Everywhere All At Once which I‚Äôve now seen three times and loved every single one: it‚Äôs one of my favourite films.

 Dan lying in bed, giving a weak "thumbs up".  Dan lying in bed, giving a weak "thumbs up". See, I‚Äôm fine! (Feel like I‚Äôve spent a lot of time lying here, this week.)
Anyway: hopefully next week I‚Äôll be feeling more normal and my poor Covid-struck brain can be trusted with code again. Until then: time to try to rest some more.
Footnotes1 Based on the World Health Organisation‚Äôs declaration of the outbreak being a pandemic on 11 March 2020 and my positive test on 19 September 2022, I stayed uninfected for two years, six months, one week, and one day. But who‚Äôs counting?

content.html:
Could have been expected to get the FTF for this one, given that it‚Äôs (a) literally 20 seconds walk from my front door and (b) the CO had indicated that one would be hidden around here, but unfortunately I contracted covid last weekend and any walk longer tab my garden was quickly leaving me exhausted. This evening I felt a little better and so the geohound and I (pictured) braved a couple of minutes in the rain to come and sign the logbook.

Note to future cachers planning to park and grab: the ‚Äúlayby‚Äù indicated is a working bus stop, albeit with an infrequent (every 2 hours, weekday daytimes) schedule, so remember to be a polite cacher and try not to park in it at times that it‚Äôll be needed by the minibus!

I might need to find a new home for my replacement to GC90RH3, whose bridge hiding place is only 100m or so (less than the requisite 0.1 miles!) from this new cache! Ah well, that‚Äôll teach me to be a slow CO!

TFTC, and for getting me out of the house for a walk for the first time since I got sick almost a week ago.

content.html:
I‚Äôve been working in Witney one day every week or two lately, but somehow I‚Äôve never managed to sync up my work times with the hours that this building is accessible! Or, when I do, I‚Äôm in a hurry and don‚Äôt have time to stop and hunt!

This morning, though, the stars aligned and I was able to get to the GZ. The cache was pretty much where I expected based on the coordinates and the hint, but still took a minute out two to lay hands on. Soon, though, I was quietly sitting and reading past log entries.

SL TFTC! FP awarded for sheer awesome.
content.value:
I‚Äôve been working in Witney one day every week or two lately, but somehow I‚Äôve never managed to sync up my work times with the hours that this building is accessible! Or, when I do, I‚Äôm in a hurry and don‚Äôt have time to stop and hunt!
This morning, though, the stars aligned and I was able to get to the GZ. The cache was pretty much where I expected based on the coordinates and the hint, but still took a minute out two to lay hands on. Soon, though, I was quietly sitting and reading past log entries.
SL TFTC! FP awarded for sheer awesome.
